transcript.text: Competition Law violations have happened at our own company, as this case study illustrates. Click on each stage of the story.

contentText.text: Unfair competition can happen anywhere, and it’s not always obvious. Not too long ago we experienced a competition law issue at Johnson Controls. Let’s look at this case to see what we can learn from it.

instructionText.text: Click on each stage of the story.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

stripBackground.img: Senior manager meeting with managers from other companies

stripCallOut.text: Johnson Controls uses certain scrap battery suppliers. For several years, a senior manager exchanged information with managers at three other large companies who also used scrap battery suppliers.
Presumably the goal was to artificially lower the prices these four companies paid to scrap battery suppliers in the territories of Germany, France, Belgium and the Netherlands.

stripBackground.img: Integrity Helpline Employee on a call

stripCallOut.text: One of Johnson Controls’ employees came forward and reported this activity through our Integrity Helpline.
Johnson Controls cooperated with the European Commission to enable a transparent investigation.
A full investigation was undertaken and resulted in the Johnson Controls manager connected to the unethical activity being dismissed.

The other companies involved received multimillion Euro fines but because Johnson Controls proactively reported the activity to the authorities and cooperated fully with their subsequent investigation, it was not fined.

The whistleblower helped Johnson Controls discover and terminate this improper practice. And by proactively reporting to the authorities, the European Commission gave Johnson Controls an immunity from fines. The fine would otherwise have been €42 million.
Following this incident, the European team at Johnson Controls implemented significant changes to our internal processes and organizational structure to prevent similar activities from recurring.
